title: Cover Picture and Issue Information
content: Female black coucal perching on a tree trunk to oversee her territory. Photo taken by Wolfgang Goymann. The authors behind this month's cover image investigated the early-life survival pathways shaping adult sex ratios (ASRs) using long-term field data and sex- and stage-specific demographic modelling of black coucals and white-browed coucalsâ€”two sympatric Centropus cuckoo species differing in mating system and the extent of sexual size dimorphism. They found no evidence that the strongly male-biased ASR of black coucals is driven by sex-specific survival during maturation, contrary to studies on shorebirds, in which sex-specific mortality of precocial young is related to ASR and mating dynamics. They suggest that factors other than early-life sex biases in survival are likely to be important in shaping ASRs and the associated mating dynamics and social behaviours in altricial coucals.
